name: AIDS Action Europe
goal:
“ AIDS: because the global fight against HIV and AIDS is what unites our members
Action: because we want to move beyond networking and towards concrete actions
Europe: because we need to collaborate on a shared agenda in Europe”
Peter van Rooijen’s spoke these words when representing AIDS Action Europe’s (AAE) interim Steering Committee at the
Open Forum on AIDS Action in Europe in March 2004.13 years later, his words have lost neither their power nor relevance.
HIV continues to be a major European public health concern, with primary issues revolving around:
→ The fact that HIV is still concentrated in key populations (men who have sex with men (MSM), people who use injection drugs (PWID), sex workers and people coming from high endemic countries).
→ The need for maintained and expanded harm reduction programmes across the region.
→ The need to promote voluntary counselling and testing (VCT) particularly within key populations, in order to ensure
diagnosis and initiation of treatment and care.
→ The need for equitable access to treatment and care across Europe, with particular attention paid to Eastern Europe
and Central Asia.
→ The need for improved access to prevention, treatment and care for migrant populations.
The AAE Steering Committee has defined an overall strategy and clear agenda spanning 2015–2017 that align AAE’s workwith these growing concerns. Through this, we will strengthen our response to the epidemic, maintain our commitments and provide a framework in which we can prioritise our actions. It is AAE’s duty to keep HIV/AIDS and co-infections as priorities on EU, national and regional health agendas. AAE will build the advocacy capacity of civil society organisations, in order to mitigate the obstacles that limit universal access to prevention, treatment, care and affordable of medicines.
Who we are
Founded in 2004, AAE is an international network comprised of 440 NGOs, networks, AIDS service organisations, activist- and community-based groups of people living with HIV (PLWH) and other key populations. Members span the EU/EEA, Central Asia, the Caucasus region and Israel.
Our Vision:
AAE’s vision is that people living with, affected by and vulnerable to HIV/AIDS enjoy a life free from stigma, discrimination and persecution, and that they have equal access to prevention, treatment, care and support across Europe and Central Asia.
Our Mission:
AAE’s mission is to connect civil society in order to work towards a more effective response to the HIV epidemic in Europe and Central Asia. We strive for the best standards of human rights protection and universal access to prevention, treatment, care and support. We aim to reduce health inequalities, paying particular attention to key populations.
Our Strategic Objectives: what we aim for:
AAE strengthens the effectiveness of civil society’s response to the HIV epidemic in the region through three strategic
objectives.
→ We serve as a gateway to members, driving forward advocacy for HIV policy change.
→ We provide a platform for regular knowledge exchange and networking.
→ We develop a stronger and more effective organisation and network.
interests: Budget, Communication, Development, Education, Employment and Social Affairs, Humanitarian Aid, Public Health, Trans-European Networks
euInitiatives:
Since the start of the EU HIV/AIDS Civil Society Forum in 2005, AAE has co-chaired the forum together with the European AIDS Treatment Group. AAE initiates and supports advocacy efforts both at international and national level in close collaboration with other stakeholders and organisations as for instance:
• Advocacy letters regarding the EU response to HIV/AIDS and broadening the scope to an integrated approach including viral Hepatitis, Tuberculosis and STIs from September 2015
• Advocacy letters to the Czech Health Ministry and to the Commissioner to abstain from mandatory testing in the Czech Republic, April/May 2015 – The Czech Government did abstain
• Letter to the Latvian Cabinet of Minister regarding the CD4 cell count for Treatment Initiation from May 2015 – The CD4 cell count increase from 200 to 350
• Letter of Concern to Commissioner Avramopoulos regarding UNGASS 2016 to advocate for a strong European position in November 2015
• Pan-European Networks and scientists call upon the Government of the Czech Republic to immediately stop the Prague Public Health Authority's persecution of people living with HIV. By now all 30 criminal charges against gay PLWHIV have been dropped.
• A letter to Vice President Timmermans and letter to CSF members to engage with their respective MoH prior to the Meeting of Ministers in Bratislava on October 2 and 3 to address the funding gap.
• STI and HIV Coordination Committee Meeting at ECDC on the 28-29 September 2016
• Latest activity: a letter to the Estonian EU-Presidency 2nd half (July-December) of 2017
• Three advocacy trainings for Affordability of Medicines in three different European regions in 2017
• European HIV Legal Forum for increased access of migrants with irregular status to HIV services and treatment in 15 European countries
• Good practice exchange of Community Based Voluntary Counselling and Testing (CBVCT) at European level
• AAE is a European delegate of the NGO Delegation to the UNAIDS Programme Coordinating Board (UNAIDS PCB) since 2016
